Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Capitaine, it's so thrilling beneath the waves, n'est-ce pas? Like anything could happen at any moment...
Sometimes I feel that way about my captaincy. I know I didn't order you to dive, Surcouf.
Non, Capitaine, you did not. Cruel irony, I dive slowly for a submarine. I find it's best to prepare for these things in advance.

Fields.MenuText: I give the orders, Surcouf, not you.
Prepare for what?
I'd appreciate being kept abreast of what my ship is doing.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, but there is always room for interpretation!
War? Intrigue? An illustrious career in swashbuckling?
I prefer expedience to honesty.
You'll find we're now perfectly positioned to strike at the Morganas up ahead. Which is that with the formation? Sin? Tout salaces...
Morganas? Why didn't you say so? I need to alert the crew!
Already taken care of, Capitaine. Shouldn't you be on the bridge by now?
Belles...
@BATTLE
Human sensors. One day they may outstrip even my own impeccable senses... but today is not that day.
Now, then... if I were a capitaine, where would I hide a safe?
Plus vite, Capitaine!
Where are you off to in such a hurry?
Racing you to the bridge, of course! There is a Morgana on the prowl!
Slow down! This is a submarine!
Your insight is such a credit to your nation.
@BATTLE
That's the last we'll see of her.
Indeed. Such a simple engagement, though... Any more like that and I may be tempted to fight sans guns.
Don't be ridiculous, Surcouf. We can't afford to let our guard down.
I am merely thinking out loud. Would Capitaine Surcouf have been content to strike from the shadows?

Fields.MenuText: You're a submarine. Act like one.
He was a pirate. He'd do whatever it took to win.
We have our orders. We'll do with them what we can.

Fields.DialogueText: You mean surprise you? I knew you'd understand!
Corsaire, Capitaine. Pirates lack a certain...élégance.
Comme je l'ai dit, Capitaine, it is all in the interpretation.
When you're ahead, minimize risk. That's how I operate.
Ah, comme c'est touchant. To view risk as something that can be turned on and off... I almost envy your worldview.
Almost?
When you have managed to arouse envy in me, you will know.
I'll look forward to it.
So shall I, for I cannot fathom what that might look like.
There you are. I've been looking everywhere for you.
Then look no further! Voulez-vous fumer, Capitaine?
Not right now, Surcouf, I... are those my cigarettes?
You wound me, Capitaine! I would not think of stealing from you.
Then where...
Not now! Elles arrivent.
The Morganas? How can you tell?
If I could answer that question, Capitaine... well, I wouldn't tell you anyway. A woman must have secrets.

Fields.MenuText: Women aren't ships.
Not from her captain.
I shouldn't have to tell a submarine not to be coy.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, nobody's perfect.
Especially from her capitaine.
Then don't, and bask in my mystique.
Besides, it's best to live in interesting times, non?
Action stations, Surcouf. And put those cigarettes back where you found them.
@BATTLE
You wanted to see me, Capitaine?
I wanted to pick up where we left off. Ever since we put to sea I've been getting more and more reports from my crew of things going missing.
How careless of your men! If they were as observant as they were brave in battle we would not be discussing this.
Ordinarily I would lay this at their feet, but when my securely locked desk is among the casualties I have to wonder. Belles can pass through solid matter, can't they?
We may decide to from time to time. Although, I would avoid doing so if I wanted to ram one of those Morganas over there.
Don't think you're off the hook, Surcouf. Expect more questions after the battle.
Toujours, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Well, I think a cigarette is well-earned after that battle.

Fields.MenuText: I hope you brought enough for everyone.
Surcouf, if I guess the brand and I'm right...
First, let's discuss your penchant for thievery.

Fields.DialogueText: You're starting to sound like our Soviet friends.
Then I am in the presence of an expert!
Honnêtement, Capitaine! You are too quick to suspect the extraordinary.
Besides, it is a filthy habit anyway. I do your men a public service...
So you admit to stealing them.
... If indeed I am guilty. You are so quick to assume. It's going to get you into trouble one day.
A toast, Capitaine!
To what? And where did you get that wine?
You ask too many questions. We must celebrate our impending victory over the Morganas!
Surcouf, the war's still on. Isn't that a bit presumptuous?
The word you are looking for is "optimistic," Capitaine. I was referring to the ones approaching us now.
The wine can wait. We have a battle to fight!
@BATTLE
Exemplary work as always, Surcouf. Now, about the wine...
Oui! This is a Muscadet, my personal favorite. It happens to be an excellent match for oysters, so if you'll follow me to the galley...
Where did you get oysters?
From the sea, Capitaine. Where else?
We'll table this for now. But from now on, I'm keeping a weather eye on our stores and on you.
I invite you to try.
If we ran the war on sense alone, where would we be? My unfortunate night blindness testifies to that.

Fields.MenuText: I get the sense you're leaving out a middleman.
Oh, well, mystery solved.
Really? Taking requests?

Fields.DialogueText: Là, tu vois? Why question fine food?
Steer me near a swordfish sometime! I relish the challenge.
You're certainly chipper today.
Naturellement. Memories of home always put me in a bright mood.
You're thinking of Cherbourg?
Oui. It is a funny thing, Capitaine; before the war, the Arsenal de Cherbourg possessed the only berth that could fully service me. Can you imagine it? To have only one place to truly rest?

Fields.MenuText: I suppose it's like finding the right person.
It's more than a little unsettling, actually.
I'd probably fight all the harder to protect it.

Fields.DialogueText: Meilleur! Can the right person refit and repair you for war?
Where is your sens de l'aventure? It is like baring one's chest and daring the enemy to fire!
True enough. I do not know much about your kind, but I know what it is to feel connected to a special place.
Don't get too lost in thought, Surcouf. We're catching up to the Morganas now.
I shall give them the warmest Cherbourg greetings!
@BATTLE
Look at them, hastening away... those that escaped.
You're amassing quite the record, Surcouf. Cherbourg would be proud.
As well she should be! But now that I think on it, a visit would not be amiss in the near future.
Well, everyone needs to recuperate sometimes.
More than recuperate! Even Cherbourg's favorite daughter has her flaws. You know I dive slowly, and I've been meaning to get my trim looked at.
You're certainly making do with what you have. I couldn't ask for a more adaptable ship.
You flatter me, Capitaine. Please continue to do so.
Tell me more about Cherbourg.
Avec plaisir! What do you want to know?
Maybe it's an odd question. Belles can't go more than a few meters  from their ships. How do you... you know... enjoy shore leave?
I was named for a resourceful man, Capitaine. The apple does not fall far. My berth happens to be within range of a bustling market and a lively tavern!
I guess even a ship can appreciate the local flavor.
I can see it all now... the fruit, the flowers, the fistfights...
Beg pardon? Fistfights?
A little sport de sang, Capitaine, nothing more. I may be immortal, but it's such a novel feeling, fighting sans guns! Head, hands, feet, and nothing more! Small wonder sailors enjoy it so.

Fields.MenuText: I'd prefer something a bit more... legal.
Do all Belles do this?
Isn't that beneath you?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose that makes you a good capitaine. Bon, mais ennuyeux...
Only the sultry and exciting ones!
Je suis un sous-marin! Nothing is beneath me.
But think of it merely as training, Capitaine. One never knows what the Morganas might do. If one decides to board us someday, I must be prepared!
With underground, bare-knuckle boxing.
I would say it keeps me humble, but humility is boring. Besides, how many of your men can boast of fighting a submarine?
I hope I never have to ask.
Tais-toi! Morganas approach. They have found me in a mood most sanguinaire! Won't you join me, Capitaine?
I think I'm content to give orders.
@BATTLE
By now I'm sure you've heard the news.
I have not. But I feel it within my soul. Cherbourg has been attacked, and France is reeling.
La Marine Nationale and the Royal Navy are conducting a joint response. Those Morganas will be at the bottom of the sea within days.
Words did not get my namesake past the British blockades. He threw even his masts overboard in the name of speed.
I wanted to make sure you knew the stakes. They're hurt, but rebuilding. This changes nothing about our mission. We continue our patrol of the northern Atlantic, and...
And watch the Vieux-Port de Marseille burn from Madeira?
You're not listening to me.
She is my home and my mother in one combined. You cannot understand!

Fields.MenuText: There are only so many of you, and Command need all the help they can get.
Save your anger for the Morganas.
This is war. Everyone loses something in the end.

Fields.DialogueText: Then there is more for me.
It will burn out when it burns out, and not sooner.
Ça suffit. There is nothing for it but blood.
We're coming up on more Morganas. Do you your worst, Surcouf.
Avec plaisir.
@BATTLE
Well done.
War is ugly, Capitaine. But that does not mean it cannot be beautiful.
Surcouf, if you need some time...
Merde. I will do my mourning on the battlefield.
If my men had your determination, we'd clean out the Atlantic within a month.
Each of us fights for what they lack most. Today I fought for my home, and I will continue to rake the Morganas with every cobble in her streets. Tomorrow...qui peut dire?
... Would you like a cigarette?
Take one of mine.
Surcouf, for the last time, I forbid it.
Je connais. I am asking you not to!
If the admirals say we maintain our patrol, we maintain our patrol. We can't risk being in one place when we're needed in another.
We dutifully maintained our patrol while Cherbourg burned, Capitaine! The powers that be cannot protect everyone!
Cherbourg was not our responsibility.
Non, Capitaine, it was mine! Robert Surcouf was offered a command by l'empereur Napoleon himself. He declined. He could do so much more unbridled by the law. So can I. So can we!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not jeopardizing the mission for revenge.
They're both dead. We're not.
I will not have my own ship raise her voice to me!

Fields.DialogueText: The butchers of Cherbourg are but a few of many! We must take this fight to them.
Do not pretend to be a stranger to history! You humans perfect the previous war just in time for the next one.
Your ship? I am a Belle! Without us your world is condamné!
No Belle disobeys a direct battle order from her captain. If I need to abuse that to keep you in line, so be it. Now, get out there, and deal with that Morgana.
Just give me a target.
@BATTLE
Je n'ai rien à te dire.
You do if I say you do. Look, I came to apologize.
Apologize for what? You are my Capitaine. I, your ship. It is not the place of the tool to question the carpenter.
You know you don't mean that. The Surcouf I know wouldn't give up this easily.
What makes you think I have? The Morganas fear me more each day.
That's not what I mean. It's all well and good to follow orders, but what's even more important is communication.

Fields.MenuText: I need to know I can trust you.
Nobody knows better than you what you're capable of.
You're not just a ship. You're a soldier.

Fields.DialogueText: You have never known. You will never know. That is why it is trust.
Then allow me to do it.
I am a corsaire. Soldiering is for those without imagination.
In any case, Capitaine, there is a Morgana fleet to fight. Command me in battle and then perhaps we will talk.
@BATTLE
Just a moment, Surcouf. That's all I ask.
Do you mean to throw yourself at my feet and beg forgiveness?
Call it what you will. All I know is that I can't run a ship when it's in open revolt.
You may certainly try.
But I wouldn't succeed. Not if we weren't working together. Besides, you'd probably find a way around me if you really tried.
Once again we can agree on something. What are you saying, Capitaine?
We still have to respect our patrol. But if you happen to sense a Morgana a bit off the beaten path... I see no reason we can't expand our jurisdiction from time to time.
Thank you, Capitaine. This means more to me than you can know.
You're named after a privateer, Surcouf. You just received your letter of marque.
Capitaine, I have a proposal.
Can it wait until after I eat?
Oui, if you do not mind my proposal becoming a decision.
... Go on.
My namesake was roi des corsaires, Capitaine. When he was refused a letter of marque, he went and captured himself a British ship with a crew a fifth of its size!

Fields.MenuText: That's remarkable, Surcouf, but what are you trying to say?
Get to the point, Surcouf.
You're saying we should turn pirate.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm saying we can do more than simply destroy our enemy.
Patience is your job, Capitaine, not mine.
We have always been corsaires. It's time we acted like it.
To truly gain the upper hand, we must turn the Morganas' own guns against them!
You're suggesting we study the Morganas?
More than study. We can incorporate the best of the salvage into my own design. This is more than a war, Capitaine - it is an arms race!
There's the alarm. Looks like the meal will have to wait. You have my attention.
@BATTLE
One less thing to worry about.
Mais quelle honte. We could learn so much more if we conducted an autopsy.
I'll tell you what, Surcouf. You have a motorboat aboard. Find eight sailors willing to go near one of those monsters and I'll approve your plan.
Simplicity itself, Capitaine. I have my methods.
Legally.
Always you challenge me! That is why I like you.
Morganas sighted! Take us under, Surcouf.
Je comprends, Capitaine.
You're oddly cooperative today. Something on your mind?
Le sang et le trésor, Capitaine. Blood and treasure.
@BATTLE
Surcouf, what are my men bringing aboard?
Ah! That will be the salvage team. I was just about to tell you when we were so rudely interrupted. Trés bien - it looks like they've scavenged one of the slattern's guns intact!

Fields.MenuText: You can't be serious.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, I am always serious. It's kept me alive so far.
I'll allow the salvage as long as we have full... and accurate... reports of its contents. And no upgrades or tinkering of any kind without my superiors' approval. Do I make myself clear?
Comme le cristal, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: Is that safe to have aboard?
Where are we going to keep it?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'll clear some space. In a compartment I can easily purge, naturellement.
Qui sait? The minute I think it is dangerous to me, out a hatch it goes.
Surcouf, how have you been feeling lately?
No worse for wear, Capitaine. Pourquoi demandez-vous?
I'm impressed and a little concerned for you. We've been fighting more and more Morganas between repairs, and on longer and longer patrols.
Per my recommendation and your permission. And we have always emerged victorious! Shall we drink to our success?
Don't change the subject. Eventually you're going to need a refit.
Allow me to assuage your concerns, Capitaine! Morgana filth crosses our path.

Fields.MenuText: Don't push yourself too hard. That's all I ask.
You're doing great things, but we can't afford to lose you.
We shouldn't get reckless out here.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing short of death is too hard. Maybe not even that...
And I cannot afford to lose a target. Quel dilemme.
Au contraire. When one appears weakest, that is when their enemy is most vulnerable!
With all due respect, Capitaine, I would look to your own health if I were you. Par exemple, someone has been stealing your jelly beans since two skirmishes ago and you have yet to notice.
I... I don't keep jelly beans in my office!
Not securely.
Surcouf, why do you know...
Make that three skirmishes. Aux armes!
@BATTLE
Surcouf, what do you make of the new Morgana salvage?
Most intriguing, Capitaine. They use metals even I've never encountered. With exceptions...
Exceptions?
Ici et là. Some of them use our markings and materiel. Quite creatively, too. Why, I once saw a Morgana bristling with German cannon where her lifeboats should have been!
Where the lifeboats should have been...?
You know, that gives me an innovative idea...
Absolutely not.
Just a suggestion.
No time for that now. There's the alarm.
@BATTLE
I hope you weren't serious before.
About the lifeboats, do you mean? Why wouldn't I be?

Fields.MenuText: You can't sacrifice safety for firepower.
Survival is not a joking matter.

Fields.DialogueText: Certain of my sisters would disagree. And when one true strike can send us to the bottom, who is to say they are wrong?
If you do not laugh, Capitaine, you cry, and I know which I prefer.

Fields.MenuText: Because you value the lives of your crew?

Fields.DialogueText: We have different ways of expressing it, Capitaine. Think of it that way.
If I appear cavalier in my conduct, Capitaine, it is because I am. I'm certain you understand.
I'm not.
To be threatened to one's core... does it not leave you feeling unmoored, if you'll pardon a pun?
You're thinking of Cherbourg.
I'm thinking of Cherbourg. If even your home were vulnerable... wouldn't you find safety wherever you could take it?
I suppose so. It's like reclaiming a space of your own from the world.
Précisément. Whatever it takes to carve a shelter from the beast's hide, is what I say.
I wouldn't pay that cost with a lifeboat.
Bien sûr, I defer to your orders... but to decide the cost of safety is a luxury, Capitaine. Bend every effort toward securing it.
That's what we're out here to do.
In different ways, I'd wager. But rest assured... the result will be the same.
*KNOCK*
It opens!
Problems, mon capitaine?
No more games, Surcouf. You know why I've called you in here.
Dear me. Might it be something to do with the Morganas nearby? Blithely plying the waves, their keels so tantalizingly exposed...
... It is now. We'll pick this up later.
Avec plaisir!
@BATTLE
How terribly thrilling! You'll have to find me a few more like them...

Fields.MenuText: Don't try and weasel your way out of our talk.
Now, where were we before that engagement?
Another one of your incidents and I just might.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't lose the thread and I will not. Always a game of catch-up with you...
Discussing my surpassing skill and beauty?
Must you always be so dour?
Your field expertise is unquestionable, Surcouf. But I can't simply ignore criminal activity on my watch.
I suppose not. Though you should be talking to the sailors about how they spend their money, and not me. Nevertheless, I'll save the poker tournaments for shore leave from now on.
I hadn't heard about those, actually.
Hadn't you? You simply must attend the next one! I'll add you to the list.
Add me to the... Hey, come back! We're not done here!
Surcouf, I want to talk to you about these poker tournaments you're...
I have no time right now, Capitaine! The Morganas are closing quickly!
Sometimes I think you're doing this on purpose...
@BATTLE
Salvage team, rapidement! Réparez ce que vous pouvez!
A word, Surcouf?
Oui, Capitaine, I believe the salvage team can handle themselves. Quoi de neuf?
I appreciate your attempts to boost morale, but I can't allow gambling among the crew.
Not even in port, Capitaine? I'm afraid I must object.

Fields.MenuText: Rampant gambling reflects poorly on the crew and on me.
Your habits are one thing, but my crew's are quite another.
You're a submarine, Surcouf, not a Mississippi riverboat.

Fields.DialogueText: Only if you lose!
Then lecture them, and not me.
A girl can dream, non?
You're at the center of it all, and I want you to put a stop to it.
It's a bit of harmless fun, Capitaine! War is said to be boring when it is not terrifying. And I have strict rules about spending more than one can afford.
... Well, I suppose if you're keeping it under control, that's better than nothing. But one word of this happening during a tour and it stops. No questions asked.
Merci beaucoup, Capitaine! I appreciate your accommodating nature.
But I have to ask... where does all the money go?
To the winner, évidemment.
And who might that be?
Ah! That is a secret for my players alone. My offer still stands if you care to join.
Noted and politely declined. As for your other activities...
Ah, j'ai oublié! You distract me so, Capitaine. If I didn't know better I'd guess you were fond of me. We must talk again soon!
Surcouf, we aren't finished!
Belles...
Capitaine! Capitaine! Morganas closing quickly! Aux armes!
Good eye, Surcouf. Meet me on the bridge in fifteen minutes.
Oui, Capitaine!
And Surcouf?
Capitaine?
Don't forget that we still need to talk.
@BATTLE
Wait just one minute, Surcouf.
Mon Capitaine, you may have it. But I really must see to the recovery efforts!

Fields.MenuText: That's exactly what worries me.
We both know there's more to it than that.
I can't let you out of my sight for a second, can I?

Fields.DialogueText: You worry too much, Capitaine. I can take care of myself.
If the Morganas left behind anything of note, there is much more!
Comment indécent! I never took you for a voyeur.
And you may rest assured that I keep only the most meticulous of records.
You're not listening. There's a discrepancy between...
Un moment...Mon dieu! Capitaine, if my senses are right, we've just brought a section of a boiler aboard! Completely intact! We'll discuss this later!
Fine. Count on it.
Surcouf, this has to stop.
Au contraire, Capitaine! You simply do not appreciate the bigger picture.
What I don't appreciate is theft. I've checked the ship's manifest, and that last Morgana left more scrap behind than we have on our records. I'm sure of it.
And I am sure you are overreacting. It appears we find ourselves at an impasse, non?

Fields.MenuText: I want to know where our salvage is going and what you're doing with it.
I'm putting a lot of faith in you, Surcouf. Don't waste it.
If I have to count every piece of salvage myself, I will.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps after we deal with these approaching Morganas.
A corsaire never wastes anything in her possession! But we tarry too much. The Morganas approach!
A most unconvincing bluff! Perhaps you should not play poker after all, and stick to the incoming Morganas.
But the alarm hasn't... Ah. There it is.
You really must learn to trust me, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
You'll forgive me if I find that difficult.
But I do so enjoy seeing you rise to a challenge. It is the mark of a daring and able capitaine. I find it truly inspiring.
Well, thank you. I do try.
In much the same way a skeet shooter is inspired by a clay pigeon.
Sorry, what was that?
I said you've made this freebooter find religion!
Capitaine.
Surcouf? Is something the matter?
Perhaps, Capitaine. It concerns the results of the salvage efforts.
Are they not satisfactory?
They are slowing. We have been able to repair and resupply from the man-made material we've recovered, but some of the Morgana technology is too... strange.
Meaning what? We have no idea what it's for or how to use it? Why didn't you tell me about this before?
Capitaine, you are overly cautious. We don't know what danger this Morgana technology could pose. How would you have reacted if I had told you as much from the start?
I would have probably disposed of it and axed the salvage program entirely.
That is why I prefer to do things my way, Capitaine. I do have one more idea, however.
I'm listening...
Let me go with the next salvage team. If we sail alongside the fleeing Morgana, perhaps I can find answers your mortal crew cannot.

Fields.MenuText: I don't like it. It's too risky.
You don't know what might be waiting for you!
And what if the Morgana fights back?

Fields.DialogueText: Ordinary men cannot chance it, but I am extraordinary. I must do extraordinary things.
Non, I do not. Hence the intrigue!
If that does not excite you, you are in the wrong business!
I suppose it's just a coincidence that you ask me this as we're approaching some Morganas.
I can't help it if my senses are impeccable.
And I can't stop you. Here's your chance. Be careful.
Toujours, Capitaine. I am nothing if not cautious.
@BATTLE
What have you found?
Something most troubling, Capitaine. I am not sure you are prepared to hear this.
Try me.
You keep a record of the goings-on aboard, do you not?
Diligently. Why?
So do the Morganas. I found a logbook, floating near the ship, following the battle. As far as I can tell, it belonged to one of them.
They... they keep logs? Records? Manifests?
They're intelligent, Capitaine. Why wouldn't they?

Fields.MenuText: What could they possibly be writing?
Have you been able to make sense of any of it?
What do they want from us?

Fields.DialogueText: It's impossible to tell right now.
Non, and I am not sure I'd like to guess.
I cannot know. It may be easier to ask what they do not want.
They are such... foreign beings. I can't decipher this at all - it's some system of writing unknown even to a linguistic savant such as myself.
So there's nothing you can glean from it. Damn! This would have been revolutionary.
Perhaps not. Our intelligence personnel might succeed where I have failed.
I'll pass it along to them.
See that you do, Capitaine. I'm sensing a Morgana to the northwest.
@BATTLE
Is that the Morgana's log? What have we found out?
Non! Je t'en supplie! You cannot read this!
Surcouf, what's going on?
It is too terrible to even imagine! Tais-toi, écoute!
... Do you hear someone screaming?
Je suis désolé, Capitaine! The men we had decode the Morgana's logs... I do not know what they saw, but they could not bear to know!
This is madness! I'm going down there to sort them out myself.
Non! Capitaine, if you value your life you will not! If you do nothing else for me in our career, do this for me. Do not go into their room. It is locked until they recover their senses.
What will the crew think? I have to say something to them.
Distract them however you can. They mustn't... Ah! Capitaine! I have the solution!
Do you sense Morganas?
Oui, bound directly for our position! Ready the crew for a fight and tell them the Morganas' fell influence causes these horrific sounds.

Fields.MenuText: I can't just lie to my men.
Just what are we trying to hide?
What could possibly be writtin in that book to cause such... this?

Fields.DialogueText: Then let me do it. I daresay I have more practice at it than you.
Something that does not wish to be found, and for once I am more than willing to comply.
I will tell you what I can after the danger has passed. There are some things best kept secret.
@BATTLE
I've had the codebreakers removed from the ship for a full psychological examination. They should be back at the base for the foreseeable future.
It is almost a mercy that they fell unconscious.
I still don't understand. How could reading something drive anyone to madness? What was in the logs?
Belles and Morganas work... differently... from mortals, Capitaine. I do not claim to know everything about our kind, but our perspective is not the same as yours.
What do you mean?
We may be enemies, but Belle and Morgana alike are born for war. We were both born... perhaps created... to destroy.
But the Morganas kill indiscriminately. You Belles are protecting mankind.
But to what end, Capitaine? Is it some affinity for humans, or do we simply oppose the Morganas? If they were not here, what purpose would we serve?

Fields.MenuText: What does that matter? You're on our side.
You are who you are. They can't take that away from you.
Get to the point. What was written?

Fields.DialogueText: By default, perhaps. Without a common enemy in the Morganas...qui sait?
And who am I? Am I Surcouf the Belle? Surcouf the spirit of French privateering?
You must understand, Capitaine, Belle and Morgana alike have a purpose. The difference is, as far as I can tell, Belles wonder why.
We Belles are capable of asking these questions. I suspect the Morganas are not. They are single-minded killers. Ruin incarnate.
Then the Morgana's logs...
Death. Violence. Bloodlust. Despair. I've never seen any being so full of darkness. Any ordinary man would buckle under so much hate.
But why? What do they gain by destroying us?
I doubt even they know. Pour autant que je sache, they cannot look beyond the present. Killing is what they are.
All the more reason to get rid of them.
We shall start with these here.
@BATTLE
Learning a lot, aren't we, Surcouf?
I destroyed the book. There was nothing more to gain from it.
I can't imagine the insanity written in it. How are the codebreakers?
Ils s'améliorent. Slowly, but surely. They have requested not to deal with Morgana intelligence again.
Tell them they won't have to. I suppose our research is at a dead end, of course.
For now. How and why the Morganas cannibalize our ships is a question we cannot answer here.

Fields.MenuText: So it's back to hunting and killing, then.
You risked a lot to get us this far. Thank you.
Does this mean you're going to relax a bit?

Fields.DialogueText: There are certainly worse ways to occupy one's time.
Thank you, Capitaine. I really don't know what I would do with myself otherwise!
Capitaine, as you've said before, this changes nothing.
I have guns to fire, a home's pride to avenge, and Morganas to destroy. That is all I need.
The Morganas will be defeated one day. We'll rebuild. What happens then?
Let us focus on today's hunt, Capitaine. We can discuss dinner when our prey is caught.
@BATTLE
Surcouf? Surcouf!
Salut, Capitaine! You're looking lively today. It suits you.
Be serious, Surcouf! I don't know how or why, but the salvage team is nowhere to be found!
Quel malheur! I wonder what could have happened to them?
What's with that smile, Surcouf? Do you know something I don't?
That may be the most beautiful question you've ever asked me.
You're in charge of them, Surcouf! Where are my men and why are they gone?
I suppose their services were no longer required. With the proceeds from the Morgana salvage, they should live quite comfortably wherever they go.

Fields.MenuText: Proceeds? You're talking about a black market!
You've been running a smuggling operation behind my back?
What on earth have you been hiding from me?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm talking about investment in the future, Capitaine.
Behind your back, under your nose, and in all sorts of interesting places.
What haven't I been hiding from you?
You were right about the missing salvage, of course. And I told you the truth.
Some of it?
Some of it. The rest of it? Well, the Spanish and Portuguese will pay a pretty penny for Morgana armor, par exemple.
And where does this money go?
To the winner, évidemment.
Is that what this war is to you? A game?
Everything is a game, Capitaine, and you are my favorite piece.
There's Morganas inbound. You and I are going to have a very long talk about all this. What you're telling me is treason.
We have a common enemy. Let us deal with her first.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Tell me everything.
Where to begin? There is so much you do not know.
How? How did the Morgana salvage disappear?
I think you do not know your men as well as you think you do. The sailors you lent me were only too happy to assist me.
What was it? Money?
Those card games may have been a bit more expensive than I let on. And I do have strict rules about spending more than you can afford.
But someone had to sign off on this. There have to be records. Who authorized the movement?
Why, you did, Capitaine. I have many requisition forms from interested scientific and underworld communities, all signed and notarized by my illustrious Capitaine.
Where did you get this? I didn't...
Attention to detail is one of my specialties, Capitaine. As is forgery.

Fields.MenuText: You're a criminal, Surcouf.
Why stoop this low? What do you hope to gain?
This is nothing short of mutiny.

Fields.DialogueText: The seas are lawless, and so must I be.
You may as well ask a tiger why it pounces.
Oh, arrêtez-le! You're making me blush.
Each of us fights for what they lack most, Capitaine. You fight for your country, for mankind, for survival, because you believe these to be threatened. And make no mistake, I fight for it too.
You're a liar. Whose side are you really on?
I hate the Morganas. I am on your side, and I'm on the Belles' side. Above all, I am on my side. I know your wars, I've seen your grudges. They are not mine.
You'll be decommissioned and scrapped if this comes out.
And you will be court-martialed, Capitaine, for building a grand smuggling empire of Morgana contraband. Perhaps executed.
So where does this leave us? What do you want from me?
Rien, Capitaine. Nothing but your cooperation. I will buy my freedom after the war is won, and you will retire like a monarch with your share.
You'd do all this just to escape your responsibility?
I may have been born for war, Capitaine, but I will choose how I die. Nor will I fire on my sisters. I owe them that much.
Remarkable. A ship giving orders to her captain...
Courage, Capitaine. There is no one else I would choose to assist me in my journey.
I'm flattered.
The Morganas are coming, Capitaine. Let us do our duty, and you may walk with me into the future.

Fields.MenuText: Well, at the very least, I'm glad to know she's on my side. For now...
She's infuriating, and... thoroughly extraordinary.
